anchors.title: Drug class
anchors.prompt: Which class does ramipril belong to?
anchors.explanation: Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor (prodrug → ramiprilat). ARBs block AT1 receptors (not ACE); CCBs and β-blockers are different classes; aliskiren is the direct renin inhibitor.

anchors.title: Common indications
anchors.prompt: Select ALL common indications for ramipril.

options.label: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

anchors.explanation: ACE inhibitors are core therapy for HTN, HFrEF, post-MI remodeling/risk reduction, and renoprotection in albuminuric CKD. They are not first-line angina anti-ischaemics and have no role in asthma.

anchors.title: Mechanism of action
anchors.prompt: Which best describes ramipril’s mechanism?

options.label: Blocks L-type Ca²⁺ channels in vascular smooth muscle

anchors.explanation: ACE inhibition reduces angiotensin II and aldosterone and increases bradykinin, producing vasodilation and natriuresis.

anchors.title: Important adverse reactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important adverse reactions of ramipril.
anchors.explanation: Cough/angioedema from bradykinin; hyperkalaemia and creatinine rise due to reduced efferent arteriolar tone; first-dose hypotension possible. Gingival hyperplasia is typical of nifedipine (CCB), not ACEIs.

anchors.title: Important drug–drug interactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important interactions with ramipril.

options.label: Potassium supplements or K-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone)

anchors.explanation: K-raising agents ↑hyperkalaemia risk; NSAIDs blunt antihypertensive/renoprotective effect and ↑AKI risk; ACEIs ↑lithium concentrations; avoid dual RAAS blockade. PPIs/macrolides are not typical interaction problems.

anchors.title: Drug class
anchors.prompt: Which class does atorvastatin belong to?
anchors.explanation: Atorvastatin is a statin; the others are different lipid or cardiovascular classes.

anchors.title: Common indications
anchors.prompt: Select ALL appropriate indications for atorvastatin.
anchors.explanation: Statins lower LDL and reduce CV events for primary/secondary prevention and in familial hypercholesterolaemia. They are not for immediate angina symptom relief and are not analgesics.

anchors.title: Mechanism of action
anchors.prompt: Which statement best describes atorvastatin’s mechanism?

options.label: Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase → ↓hepatic cholesterol synthesis; ↑LDL receptors
Inhibits ACE to reduce Ang II
Only upregulates hepatic LDL receptors without affecting synthesis

anchors.explanation: Primary action is enzyme inhibition; LDL-receptor upregulation is a downstream effect. The other mechanisms are unrelated.

anchors.title: Important adverse reactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important adverse reactions of atorvastatin.
anchors.explanation: Muscle symptoms and LFT elevation are the key concerns; GI upset is common; there is a small increase in diabetes risk. Dry cough is typical of ACEIs; ankle oedema is more typical with dihydropyridine CCBs.

anchors.title: Important drug–drug interactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important interactions with atorvastatin.

options.label: Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., clarithromycin, azoles, HIV protease inhibitors)

anchors.explanation: CYP3A4 inhibitors and grapefruit increase statin levels → ↑myopathy risk; fibrates further increase myopathy risk. Warfarin/ACEIs are not primary interaction concerns for atorvastatin.

anchors.title: Drug class
anchors.prompt: Which class does bisoprolol belong to?
anchors.explanation: Bisoprolol is a cardioselective (β1-predominant) β-blocker.

anchors.title: Common indications
anchors.prompt: Select ALL appropriate indications for bisoprolol.
anchors.explanation: Used across HTN/angina/HFrEF and AF rate control. Avoid in asthma (bronchospasm); bisoprolol is not a standard choice for migraine prophylaxis compared with propranolol.

anchors.title: Mechanism of action
anchors.prompt: Which best describes bisoprolol’s mechanism?

options.label: Blocks cardiac β1-adrenergic receptors → ↓HR/contractility and ↓renin release
Inhibits Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits ACE to reduce Ang II

anchors.explanation: β1 blockade reduces chronotropy/inotropy and renin secretion. The other options are distinct mechanisms.

anchors.title: Important adverse reactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important adverse reactions of bisoprolol.
anchors.explanation: Typical β-blocker effects: bradyarrhythmia, fatigue, bronchospasm (loss of β2-mediated bronchodilation), cold peripheries, sexual dysfunction. Dry cough is characteristic of ACE inhibitors, not β-blockers.

anchors.title: Important drug–drug interactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important interactions with bisoprolol.
anchors.explanation: Additive AV-nodal depression with non-DHP CCBs, digoxin, and amiodarone; clonidine withdrawal can cause rebound hypertension exacerbated by β-blockade. Nitrates are generally safe with β-blockers.

anchors.title: Drug class
anchors.prompt: Which class does metformin belong to?
anchors.explanation: Metformin is a biguanide; it is not a secretagogue (sulfonylurea) nor DPP-4/SGLT2 inhibitor.

anchors.title: Common indications
anchors.prompt: Select ALL appropriate indications for metformin.

options.label: Polycystic ovary syndrome (insulin resistance; off-label/common practice)
Weight loss in euglycaemic patients (sole indication)

anchors.explanation: First-line for T2DM and commonly used for PCOS-related insulin resistance. It is not used for T1DM alone, not for DKA, and not as a stand-alone obesity drug in euglycaemia.

anchors.title: Mechanism of action
anchors.prompt: Which best describes metformin’s mechanism?
anchors.explanation: AMPK activation reduces hepatic glucose output and improves insulin sensitivity; it does not stimulate insulin secretion or affect SGLT2/DPP-4.

anchors.title: Important adverse reactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL clinically important adverse reactions of metformin.

options.label: Lactic acidosis (rare; risk ↑ in renal/hepatic failure or hypoxia)
Vitamin B12 deficiency with long-term use

anchors.explanation: GI effects are common; rare lactic acidosis is the key serious risk; B12 can fall over time. Metformin alone does not usually cause hypoglycaemia and does not cause weight gain.

anchors.title: Important drug–drug/intervention interactions
anchors.prompt: Select ALL interactions of concern with metformin.

options.label: Iodinated contrast in patients with renal impairment

anchors.explanation: Contrast and alcohol can precipitate lactic acidosis; cimetidine can raise metformin levels by reducing renal secretion. Warfarin/PPIs are not key metformin interactions.
